subject: Re: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
msgSnippet: ... The only important thing is whether the application works. Whatever else  we evaluate, whether it is the number of asserts, the number of tests, the number
messageBody:
Jason Rogers wrote:

> I respectfully disagree. You assume that asserts and test cases are equal
> in their importance. What I want to know is whether or not a test has
> passed. ... So, why count asserts? Perhaps to give
> that warm, fuzzy feeling... perhaps for some other reason.

The only important thing is whether the application works. Whatever else we
evaluate, whether it is the number of asserts, the number of tests, the number
of test cases, or even whether we test at all, is just there to give us that
"warm, fuzzy feeling" or to give us the shivers. The number of tests/asserts
doesn't prove anything but it does give us a hint at an appropriate body
temperature.

I guess this whole discussion really boils down to what constitutes a test. I
choose to organize my tests so that I generally have one test per tested method,
with appropriately many asserts per test. Other programmers might want to
refactor my test code so that basically one assert per test was the rule. This
is probably just a matter of taste. If so, it would be nice if JUnit would
support both approaches - displaying the number of tests _and_ the number of
asserts.

- Tom
